name: Extract - Mini 3 Gal/11.3 l Batch
notes: Extract batch with a 3 gal/11l target batch volume designed to fit in a 3 gal pot.  Uses about 1 gal/4 liters of top-up water.

name: All Grain - Standard 5 Gal/19l Batch - Cooler
notes: Popular all grain setup.  5 Gal/19 l Plastic cooler as mash tun with false bottom, and 7-9 gallon brewpot capable of boiling at least 7 gal of wort without spilling over.  Primarily used for single infusion mashes.

name: Extract - Standard 5 Gal/19 l Batch
notes: Extract Setup for 5 gal/19 l brew pot - leaving a workable boil volume of around 4.5 gal.   Used for extract or partial mash brewing.  Note top-up water is still required as we can't reach a full volume boil in this setup.

name: BIAB - Standard 5 Gal/19 l Batch
notes: Sample Brew-In-A-Bag equipment profile set up for a 15 Gal/50 litre brew pot (diameter of 40cm or 16 inches) using a polyester grain bag to hold the grain.  This profile should be used with the BIAB mash profiles available in the BeerSmith mash profiles area.  The above assumes loose pellet hops and only clear, chilled wort transferred from the kettle using no trub management techniques. Experienced brewers should adjust 'Loss to Trub and Chiller' and 'Brewhouse Efficiency' accordingly to suit their trub management techniques.

name: BIAB - Large 10 Gal/38 l Batch
notes: Sample Brew-in-a-bag equipment profile set up for a 20 Gal/70 liter brewing pot  (diameter of 45cm or 18 inches) and using a polyester grain bag to hold the grain.  This profile should be used with the BIAB mash profiles available in the BeerSmith mash profiles area. The above assumes loose pellet hops and only clear, chilled wort transferred from the kettle using no trub management techniques. Experienced brewers should adjust 'Loss to Trub and Chiller' and 'Brewhouse Efficiency' accordingly to suit their trub management techniques. Careful when mashing in as this profile approaches the pot limits.

name: All Grain - Large 10 Gal/38 l - Stainless
notes: Popular 10 gal/38 l batch setup for all grain brewing.  Uses two large stainless 15 gal/58 l kegs or pots for the boil pot and mash tun with the tops cut off the keg.  A third keg or large pot is often used as a pot to heat mash tun water.

name: All Grain - Large 10 Gal/38 l - Cooler
notes: Popular 10 gallon/38 liter setup for all grain brewing.  Uses a 10 gal/38 l water cooler as mash tun for single infusion mashes and a 15 gallon brew pot for full size boil of the 12+ gallons of wort.

name: Wine - Large 12 Gal/46 l Batch
notes: Double wine kit size - starts with 12 gal/46 l of wine one or more buckets or carboys.  Primary fermentation is often done in a large palstic bucket or fermenter and secondary and later phases are often done in carboy to minimize oxygen.

name: All Grain - Mini 3 Gal/11.3 l - BIAB Stovetop
notes: Mini Brew-in-a-bag stovetop all grain batch with a  a 3 gal/11l target batch volume designed to fit in a 5-6 gal pot.  Note that pot size dictates how much grain can be used and you may need more than 5 gal/19 l for higher gravity beers.  Please use a BIAB mash profile with this setup to get the proper mash volumes.

name: Extract - Large 10 Gal/38 l Batch
notes: Large 10 gal/38 l batch setup for all extract brewing.  Uses 10 gal boil pot and 4 gal of top up water to avoid boil-overs.

name: Mead - Mini 3 Gal/11.3 l Batch
notes: Mead mini batch with a 3 gal/11.3 l starting volume and no-boil method.  Primary fermentation is usually done in a 5 gal/19 l bucket, and secondary is often done in glass or mini-kegs to avoid oxygen during longer aging periods.

name: Mead - Large 10 Gal/38 l Batch
notes: Mead setup for the serious mead maker fermenting 10 gal/38 l at a time.  No boil method.  Uses 15 Gal bucket or keg for primary fermentation and carboys or kegs for aging.

name: Mead - Micro 1 Gal/4 l Batch
notes: Tiny 1 gal/4 liter mead setup.  No boil method.  Primary fermentation is done in a small 1.5-2 gal (6-8 l) bucket.  Secondary and later fermentation is done in a 1 gal/4 l glass jug.

name: Wine - Mini - 3 Gal/11.3 l Batch
notes: Half size mini wine batch or 3 gal/11 liter kit size - often used for dessert wines or small test batches.  Primary fermentation is done in a 5 gal/19 l bucket and later fermentations can be done in a small carboy or mini-keg.

name: Wine - Standard 6 Gal/23 l
notes: Most popular wine kit size - starts with 6 gal/23 l of wine in a 7.5-9 gal (30-35 l) bucket or carboy.  Primary fermentation is often done in a large palstic bucket and secondary and later phases are often done in carboy to minimize oxygen.

name: Mead - Standard 5 Gal/19 l Batch
notes: Standard 5 gal/19 liter mead setup for no-boil mead.  Typically the primary fermenter is a 7.5 gal/28 l or larger plastic bucket for easy of access.  Meads are usually aged in glass carboys or kegs to avoid oxygen contamination during long aging periods.

name: Cider - Large 10 Gal/38 l Batch
notes: Double size 10 gal/38 liter setup for no-boil cider.  Typically the primary fermenter is a large plastic bucket or fermenter for easy of access.  Cider is often aged in a carboy or keg.

name: Cider - Mini 3 Gal/11.3 l Batch
notes: Mini 3 Gal/11.3 setup for no-boil cider.  Typically the primary fermenter is a  5 gal/19 l or larger plastic bucket for easy of access.  Cider is often aged in a carboy or keg.

name: All Grain - Standard 5 Gal/19l Batch - Stainless
notes: Popular all grain setup.  5 Gal/19 l stainless pot as mash tun with false bottom, and 7-9 gallon brewpot capable of boiling at least 7 gal of wort without spilling over.  Primarily used for single infusion mashes.

name: Cider - Standard 5 Gal/19 l Batch
notes: Standard 5 gal/19 liter setup for no-boil cider.  Typically the primary fermenter is a 7.5 gal/28 l or larger plastic bucket for easy of access.  Cider is often aged in a carboy or keg.

name: ANVIL Foundry 6.5 (2.5 gal batch) size
notes: This profile is for the no-sparge method.  If you are using a sparge method, you will need to increase efficiency and volumes accordingly.  For 240V operation increase boiloff rate to 1 gal/hr at 100% power, or run at 60% power for similar boil off rate at 120V operation.

name: ANVIL Foundry 10.5 (5 gal batch) size
notes: This profile is for the no-sparge method.  If you are using a sparge method, you will need to increase efficiency and volumes accordingly.  For 240V operation increase boiloff rate to 1 gal/hr at 100% power, or run at 60% power for similar boil off rate at 120V operation.

name: BREWHA BIAC (Large) 120L/32 gallon beer
notes: Boil off calculated based on 60 minute boil. During the boil, a power output of 75% is recommended to yeild a approx 6% evaporation/hour, however, a higher or lower output maybe used depending on the amount of evaporation desired. The ‘Loss to Trub’ is the removal of hot break that has settled to the bottom of the cone at the end of the chilling after boil, removed before pitching yeast. Fermenter loss is due to ~4.5L in the cone below the racking port. These numbers can be adjusted as needed. Mash Colander volume is about 170L and volume under the Mash Colander is about 35L.

name: BREWHA BIAC (Large) 180L/48 gallon beer
notes: Boil off calculated based on 60 minute boil. During the boil, a power output of 75% is recommended to yeild a approx 6% evaporation/hour, however, a higher or lower output maybe used depending on the amount of evaporation desired. The ‘Loss to Trub’ is the removal of hot break that has settled to the bottom of the cone at the end of the chilling after boil, removed before pitching yeast. Fermenter loss is due to ~4.5L in the cone below the racking port. These numbers can be adjusted as needed. Mash Colander volume is about 170L and volume under the Mash Colander is about 35L.

name: BREWHA BIAC (Medium) 19L/5 gallon beer
notes: Boil off calculated based on 90 minute boil. During the boil, a power output of 100% is recommended to boil off the excess water that was added for mash, however, a lower output maybe used depending on the amount of evaporation desired. The ‘Loss to Trub’ is the removal of hot break that has settled to the bottom of the cone at the end of the chilling after boil, removed before pitching yeast. Fermenter loss is due to ~1.8L in the cone below the racking port. These numbers can be adjusted as needed. Mash Colander volume is about 56L and volume under the Mash Colander is about 22L.

name: BREWHA BIAC (Medium) 38L/10 gallon beer
notes: Boil off calculated based on 60 minute boil. During the boil, a power output of 50-75% is recommended to yeild a approx 6% evaporation/hour, however, a higher or lower output maybe used depending on the amount of evaporation desired. The ‘Loss to Trub’ is the removal of hot break that has settled to the bottom of the cone at the end of the chilling after boil, removed before pitching yeast. Fermenter loss is due to ~1.8L in the cone below the racking port. These numbers can be adjusted as needed. Mash Colander volume is about 56L and volume under the Mash Colander is about 22L.

name: BREWHA BIAC (Medium) 57L/15 gallon beer
notes: Boil off calculated based on 60 minute boil. During the boil, a power output of 50-75% is recommended to yeild a approx 6% evaporation/hour, however, a higher or lower output maybe used depending on the amount of evaporation desired. The ‘Loss to Trub’ is the removal of hot break that has settled to the bottom of the cone at the end of the chilling after boil, removed before pitching yeast. Fermenter loss is due to ~1.8L in the cone below the racking port. These numbers can be adjusted as needed. Mash Colander volume is about 56L and volume under the Mash Colander is about 22L.

name: BREWHA BIAC (Small) 12L/3 gallon beer
notes: Boil off calculated based on 60 minute boil. During the boil, a power output of 50-75% is recommended to yeild a approx 6% evaporation/hour, however, a higher or lower output maybe used depending on the amount of evaporation desired. The ‘Loss to Trub’ is the removal of hot break that has settled to the bottom of the cone at the end of the chilling after boil, removed before pitching yeast. Fermenter loss is due to ~1.8L in the cone below the racking port. These numbers can be adjusted as needed. Mash Colander volume is about 16L and volume under the Mash Colander is about 7L.

name: BREWHA BIAC (Small) 19L/5 gallon beer
notes: Boil off calculated based on 60 minute boil. During the boil, a power output of 50-75% is recommended to yeild a approx 6% evaporation/hour, however, a higher or lower output maybe used depending on the amount of evaporation desired. The ‘Loss to Trub’ is the removal of hot break that has settled to the bottom of the cone at the end of the chilling after boil, removed before pitching yeast. Fermenter loss is due to ~1.8L in the cone below the racking port. These numbers can be adjusted as needed. Mash Colander volume is about 16L and volume under the Mash Colander is about 7L.

name: BREWHA BIAC 3BBL Micro-brewery 350L/3BBL beer
notes: Boil off calculated based on 60 minute boil. During the boil, a power output of 50-75% is recommended to yeild a approx 6% evaporation/hour, however, a higher or lower output maybe used depending on the amount of evaporation desired. The Mash Tun Addition is the volume under the Mash Colander. The ‘Loss to Trub’ is the removal of hot break that has settled to the bottom of the cone at the end of the chilling after boil, removed before pitching yeast. Fermenter loss is due to ~10L in the cone below the racking port and/or yeast volume. These numbers can be adjusted as needed.

name: BREWHA BIAC 5BBL Micro-brewery 585L/5BBL beer
notes: Boil off calculated based on 60 minute boil. During the boil, a power output of 50-75% is recommended to yeild a approx 6% evaporation/hour, however, a higher or lower output maybe used depending on the amount of evaporation desired. Mash Tun Addition is the volume under the Mash Colander. The ‘Loss to Trub’ is the removal of hot break that has settled to the bottom of the cone at the end of the chilling after boil, removed before pitching yeast. Fermenter loss is due to ~15L in the cone below the racking port and/or yeast volume. These numbers can be adjusted as needed. Remember to tap the bottom of the Colander with mash paddle prior to mashing in to release any air pockes that may be trapped beneath.

name: 7.5 Gallon BoilerMaker™ (5 gal/19 L)
notes: Popular 5 gallon batch setup for all grain brewing. Uses a 7.5 gal BoilerMaker™ for the mash tun and a 10 gal BoilerMaker™ for the boil kettle. A third BoilerMaker™ is often used as a hot liquor tank.

name: 10 Gallon BoilerMaker™ (5 gal/19 L)
notes: Popular 5 gallon batch setup for all grain brewing.  Uses a 10 gal BoilerMaker™ for the mash tun and a 10 gal BoilerMaker™ for the boil kettle.  A third BoilerMaker™ is often used as a hot liquor tank.

name: 20 Gallon BoilerMaker™ (15 gal/57 L)
notes: Popular 15 gallon batch setup for all grain brewing. Uses a 20 gal BoilerMaker™ for the mash tun and a 30 gal BoilerMaker™ for the boil kettle. A third BoilerMaker™ is often used as a hot liquor tank.

name: 30 Gallon BoilerMaker™ (20 gal/76 L)
notes: Popular 20 gallon batch setup for all grain brewing. Uses a 30 gal BoilerMaker™ for the mash tun and a 30 gal BoilerMaker™ for the boil kettle. A third BoilerMaker™ is often used as a hot liquor tank.

name: 15 Gallon BoilerMaker™ (10 gal/ 38 L)
notes: Popular 10 gallon batch setup for all grain brewing. Uses a 15 gal BoilerMaker™ for the mash tun and a 20 gal BoilerMaker™ for the boil kettle. A third BoilerMaker™ is often used as a hot liquor tank.

name: 55 Gallon BoilerMaker™ (1 Bbl/120 L)
notes: Popular 1 barrel batch setup for all grain brewing. Uses a 55 gal BoilerMaker™ for the mash tun and a 55 gal BoilerMaker™ for the boil kettle. A third BoilerMaker™ is often used as a hot liquor tank.

name: Blichmann Engineering Pro Pilot 10 gal batch
notes: This profile is for both the electric and gas horizontal Pro Pilot systems.  The 10 gal batch size system uses a 20 gal boil kettle, 15 gal mash tun, and a 15 gal hot liquor tank.  Wort losses based on a moderately hoppy beer.  Increase losses for heavily hopped styles.

name: Blichmann Engineering Pro Pilot 20 gal batch
notes: This profile is for both the electric and gas horizontal Pro Pilot systems.  The 20 gal batch size system uses a 30 gal boil kettle, 30 gal mash tun, and a 30 gal hot liquor tank.  Wort losses based on a moderately hoppy beer.  Increase losses for heavily hopped styles.

name: Blichmann Engineering Pro Pilot 32 gal batch
notes: This profile is for both the electric and gas horizontal Pro Pilot systems.  The 32 gal (1 BBL) batch size system uses a 55  gal boil kettle, 55 gal mash tun, and a 55 gal hot liquor tank.  Wort losses based on a moderately hoppy beer.  Increase losses for heavily hopped styles.

name: Blichmann Engineering Pro Pilot 5 gal batch
notes: This profile is for both the electric and gas horizontal Pro Pilot systems.  The 5 gal batch size system uses a 10 gal boil kettle, 10 gal mash tun, and a 10 gal hot liquor tank.  Wort losses based on a moderately hoppy beer.  Increase losses for heavily hopped styles.

name: Braumeister - 20 Litre
notes: For the Braumeister 20l brewing system.  Recommend using any of the "BIAB" or Brew-in-a-bag mash profiles in recipes with this equipment profile.

name: Braumeister 50L
notes: "Sparge" with 1L 78C water per kg of grain.

name: Brew-Boss Pro 54 Gallon Kettle 31 Gallon Net Batch
Brew-Boss Pro 54 Gallon Kettle 15.5 Gallon Net Batch
Brew-Boss 20 Gallon Kettle 5 Gallon Net Batch
notes: Equipment profile for a 5 gallon batch in a 15 gallon Brew-Boss Automated Electric Brewing system.

name: Brew-Boss 20 Gallon Kettle 15 Gallon Batch
notes: Equipment profile for a 10 gallon batch in a 20 gallon Brew-Boss Automated Electric Brewing system.

name: Brew-Boss 20 Gallon Kettle 10 Gallon Batch
notes: Equipment profile for a 10 gallon batch in a 20 gallon Brew-Boss Automated Electric Brewing system.

name: Brew-Boss 15 Gallon Kettle 5 Gallon Batch
notes: Equipment profile for a 5 gallon batch in a 15 gallon Brew-Boss Automated Electric Brewing system.

name: Brew-Boss 15 Gallon Kettle 10 Gallon Batch
notes: Equipment profile for a 10 gallon batch in a 15 gallon Brew-Boss Automated Electric Brewing system.

name: Brew-Boss 10 Gallon Kettle 5 Gallon Batch
notes: Equipment profile for a 5 gallon batch in a 15 gallon Brew-Boss Automated Electric Brewing system.

name: PicoBrew Zymatic
notes: First attempt at Picobrew Zymatic Beersmith profile.  Adjusted Lauter Tun Deadspace after measuring ~12oz. of leftover product.  Adjusted again using Pre-Boil SG and Pos-Boil SG.  Matched Cooling Shrinkage to Boil off rate then adjusted based on observations.  Setting Brewhouse Eff to 65% based off of average of three sessions so far.

name: ROBOBREW
notes: Equipment Profile created by Brian from Short Circuited Brewers. Any questions comments or concerns can be direct to Brian@shortcircuitedbrewers.com

notes: Profile for Ruby Street Brewing  - Alpha Ruby™ 1 BBL Brewing System Equipped with 45 Gallon Kettles
